title: Report: Attacks on Churches Increased 800% in 6 Years
text:
Attacks on churches have increased nearly 800 percent in less than six years, indicating that ‚Äúhostility against U.S. churches is not only on the rise but also accelerating,‚Äù a Family Research Council (FRC) report found .
Between 2018 and 2023, FRC identified 915 acts of hostility against churches in the United States by analyzing open-source documents, reports, and media outlets. In just the last year alone (between January and November of 2023), 436 acts of hostility against churches occurred, according to the report.
‚ÄúThis was more than double the number of incidents in all 12 months of 2022, which was 195. It also marked the second consecutive year that saw more than twice the number of incidents of the year before,‚Äù the report states. ‚ÄúThere were at least 96 incidents in 2021, 55 in 2020, 83 in 2019, and 50 in 2018. Over the entire reporting period for this report, from 2018 to 2023, acts of hostility appear to have increased in frequency over time‚Äù
The report notes that the increase ‚Äúcould be due in part to increased public reporting on crimes against churches, resulting in more available data than in the past.‚Äù
It‚Äôs all connected. The Left‚Äôs coordinated use of ‚ÄúChristian nationalism‚Äù and the rise in hostility against houses of worship. It‚Äôs an intimidation game designed to silence Christians and suppress our votes. Don‚Äôt buy it.
Keep praying ‚Äî keep standing ‚Äî keep voting ‚Äî for‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/Apj9mMVUwP
‚Äî Tony Perkins (@tperkins) February 22, 2024
By category, 315 attacks in 2023 were vandalisms, 75 were arson attacks or arson attempts, ten were gun-related, 20 were bomb threats, and 37 fell in the ‚Äúother‚Äù category. Seventeen incidents fell into multiple categories, according to the report.
Between 2018 and 2023, there were at least 709 occurrences of vandalism, 135 arson attacks or attempts, 22 gun-related incidents, 32 bomb threats, and 61 other incidents (assault, threats, interruption of worship services, etc.). In 39 cases, multiple types of hostility occurred (e.g., vandalism and arson), the report states.
The incidents occurred in all 50 states and the District of Columbia, although states with larger populations tended to report more incidents.
üö® NEW REPORT!
Hostility against churches is on the rise in the United States.
-2023 (Jan-Nov) saw a significant increase in acts of hostility against churches; we identified 436 incidents.
-This was more than double the number of incidents in all 12 months of 2022, which was‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/klWe6X45vj
‚Äî Family Research Council (@FRCdc) February 20, 2024
According to the FRC, the motives of most of incidents are unknown, although many attacks had political overtones and several were overtly Satanic. At least 59 of the churches in the report were repeat victims with verifiable timeframes of the incidents, according to the FRC.
‚ÄúSome acts of vandalism against churches appeared to have been motivated by anger toward the targeted church. Other acts appeared to have a political motivation. Some incidents appeared to have been committed by juveniles or persons struggling with mental illness,‚Äù the report states. ‚ÄúSeveral instances of vandalism also involved theft. Many acts of vandalism against churches were under criminal investigation; a minority were under investigation as hate crimes. Police were often unable to identify the vandals.‚Äù
The longest section of the report is a 97-page list of attacks on churches, which are corroborated by 50 pages of endnotes.
Standout cases include several incidents of transgender violence against churches. The most shocking incident was the March 27 shooting at Nashville Covenant School. Trans-identifying Audrey Hale reportedly shot and killed six people, including three young students. Hale, who went by the male name ‚ÄúAiden,‚Äù left behind a manifesto, most of which law enforcement refused to release, although a few pages were leaked .
HOPE & HEALING: About 500 worshippers gathered to sing and pray at ‚ÄúA Day of Prayer‚Äù Christian revival tour ‚Äî a partnership between Let Us Worship and TPUSA Faith ‚Äî earlier this month in Nashville in the wake of the Covenant Christian school shooting. pic.twitter.com/M42hGP9Tau
‚Äî Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) April 10, 2023
The report lists another attack on January 3, 2023, by a man named Cameron Storer who identifies as a female. Storer is accused of setting fire to Portland Korean Church, a 117-year-old historic vacant building. Storer told investigators that he heard voices telling him to burn the church down.
On March 3, 2023, St. Joseph Catholic Church in Louisville, Kentucky, was vandalized with the painted message: ‚ÄúTRANS PWR.‚Äù The incident occurred after the state legislature overrode the Democrat governor‚Äôs veto of a bill that protects minors for sex mutilating surgeries.
Louisville Catholic church hit with 'TRANS PWR' graffiti after House OK's gender bill https://t.co/Ma5XWC8dHV
‚Äî Courier Journal (@courierjournal) March 3, 2023
A number of incidents were linked to pro-abortion hostility after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022. And ‚Äúat least 12 incidents included satanic imagery or symbols,‚Äù the report notes, listing several examples.
The FRC said it ‚Äúset out to analyze publicly available data to better understand the problem and determine whether there has been a statistically significant increase over time‚Äù due to ‚Äúthe perceived increased in acts of hostility against churches in the United States.‚Äù The FRC released the February report following a similar report on incidents that occurred between January 2018 and September 2022.
The FRC said the report is not comprehensive and that ‚Äúm any acts of hostility against churches are likely not reported to authorities and/or are not featured in the news or other online sources from which we collected data.‚Äù
‚ÄúThus, the number of acts of hostility is undoubtedly much higher than the number reflected in this report. This report is intended to compile the publicly reported data and identify any trends,‚Äù the report states.
Author of the report Arielle Del Turco noted that while the motivations of many attacks are unknown, ‚Äúthe rise in crimes against churches is taking place in a context in which American culture appears increasingly hostile to Christianity.‚Äù She wrote:
Criminal acts of vandalism and destruction of church property may be symptomatic of a collapse in societal reverence and respect for houses of worship and religion‚Äîin this case, churches and Christianity Americans appear increasingly comfortable lashing out against church buildings, pointing to a larger societal problem of marginalizing core Christian beliefs, including those that touch on hot-button political issues related to human dignity and sexuality. Attacks on houses of worship may also signal a discomfort with religion in general.
‚ÄúThe free exercise of religion has always been an essential component of American society and is enshrined in the U.S. Constitution as a basic right,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúAttempts to prevent religious exercise through threats or violence should be soundly condemned by anyone who values the First Amendment.‚Äù

author: Eva Kolimar
title: Clean Up Australia Day clears 1.42 tonnes of litter
text:
Efforts in the 35th Clean Up Australia Day were successful, with groups participating in the annual event across 26 sites in St George.
Georges River Council supported volunteers and helped remove over 1.42 tonnes of litter collected from parks, streets, and creeks.
From community groups, childcare centres and club centres to schools, gardens, parks and wetlands, people gloved up and got their hands dirty to spruce the environment.
Items collected included plastic drink bottles and bags, disposable coffee cups, cigarette butts and polystyrene.
The more unusual items included a basketball stand, children's toys, balls, a surf ski, a surfboard cover, car parts, tyres, and cash.
Georges River Council mayor Elise Borg said seeing so many people volunteer was impressive.
"[Their] dedication and hard work significantly impact keeping Georges River beautiful," she said. " It's inspiring to see so many individuals coming together with a shared vision for a cleaner, greener future."
Clean Up Australia Day has become the nation's largest community-based environmental event, held annually on the first Sunday in March.

author: James Wilson
title: 'He's my King' - Why a Monaghan village still loves the British monarchy | Newstalk
text: The Stewart family home might be in County Monaghan but they still identify as British - and act accordingly. Every Christmas Day at 3pm, the King‚Äôs Christmas message is switched on and the family stand respectfully when the British National Anthem is played. ‚ÄúYou can see among Dad‚Äôs stuff, there‚Äôs a plate behind us there, that‚Äôs uncle Fred‚Äôs and it‚Äôs of King George,‚Äù Mr Stewart said. ‚ÄúYou would find that throughout this area, loads of stuff like that in people‚Äôs houses where the monarchy was very much at the heart of people‚Äôs culture and mindset.‚Äù Despite this, Mr Stewart admits attitudes towards the new King Charles are tepid and, like many Britons, he misses Queen Elizabeth. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not the same warmth to Charles,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs because there was something special about the Queen. ‚ÄúAlthough, we would still recognise Charles as King; I would render unto Caesar what‚Äôs due to Caesar. ‚ÄúHe is my King and I have respect for him.‚Äù Journalist and author Mary Kenny was five-years-old in 1949 but has vivid memories of the day Ireland became a Republic. ‚ÄúMy brother James brought me to the Dodder River, which looked over towards Ringsend,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere was a huge fireworks display which was celebrating the declaration of the Republic and it seemed absolutely wonderful to me as a child. ‚ÄúI was a bit confused in some way because I thought, with some reason, that the Republic had been declared in 1916. ‚ÄúThen I came to understand that √âire was leaving the Commonwealth of British Nations and declaring a full Republic - something that did become quite controversial.‚Äù When Ireland became independent in 1922, the new Free State had reluctantly become a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. It meant the British monarch remained Ireland‚Äôs head of state - a fact that led many disgusted TDs to oppose the Anglo-Irish Treaty. In 1937, a new Constitution had been drawn up that contained no reference whatsoever to the Crown and Winston Churchill described Ireland as ‚Äúneither in nor out‚Äù of the Commonwealth. Confusingly though, the External Relations (Executive Authority) Act of 1936 had empowered the British monarch to sign letters of credence for Irish diplomats. In all other aspects, power and authority rested completely with the Oireachtas. The final break was announced in 1948, when Taoiseach John A. Costello announced Ireland would leave the Commonwealth and officially declare the nation a republic. Decades on, Fine Gael considers the decision one of its greatest achievements in office. ‚ÄúIt had been said by Michael Collins and others, Kevin O‚ÄôHiggins, around the time of the Civil War and the early years of our State that the Free State was a stepping stone,‚Äù Fine Gael TD Charlie Flanagan told Newstalk. ‚ÄúCertainly, the completion [of that stepping stone] was the declaration of the Republic and interestingly enough, in order to ensure there was a Fine Gael stamp on it, when Costello took the bill through the D√°il towards enactment, he took it as Taoiseach - which was unusual. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt left to the line Minister at the time, which would have been Se√°n McBride, who at the time was Minister for External Affairs.‚Äù However, the decision upset some Fine Gael supporters from the Protestant community, many of whom valued the connection Commonwealth membership provided with Britain and other English-speaking countries around the world. While researching her book, Crown and Shamrock: Love and Hate Between Ireland and the British Monarchy, Mary Kenny found a number of Irish people had written to King George, bidding him farewell. ‚ÄúMrs Dorris Weir, who attended the Church of Ireland in Irishtown, wrote to the King to say it was like a farewell and she was really sorry they wouldn‚Äôt pray for the King anymore in the Church of Ireland,‚Äù Ms Kenny said. ‚ÄúThey would now be obliged to pray for the President and they would no longer be allowed to sing God Save The King - which they had done. ‚ÄúShe wrote to say she would still maintain feelings of love towards this institution and the King did send a nice letter. ‚ÄúIt was kind of the end of an era for Irish Protestants of the time.‚Äù 'Part of a discussion' Not long after Ireland left the Commonwealth, India indicated it wished to become a republic while remaining a member of the organisation. The London Declaration of 1949 announced a compromise; member states could abolish the monarchy but remain part of the Commonwealth if they recognised the British monarch as ‚Äúthe symbol of the free association of its independent member nations and as such the Head of the Commonwealth.‚Äù Ireland decided not to re-apply for membership but Deputy Charles Flanagan feels it is conversation worth having in the event of a border poll. ‚ÄúI think there was a reluctance on the part of the Irish people to [rejoin] what was then the British Commonwealth,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe had fought hard for our independence, we had spilt blood for our independence. ‚ÄúSo, I‚Äôm not sure if there were circumstances under which, in the 1950s, we would have re-joined the British Commonwealth. ‚ÄúHowever, 70 years later circumstances have changed; it‚Äôs no longer the British Commonwealth and it‚Äôs mainly a body that engages in trade, sport and culture. ‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt believe that the majority of the Irish people, if asked, would support the rejoining of the Commonwealth but I do think it‚Äôs something that obviously will have to be part of a discussion should there be, at some stage in the future, a united Ireland.‚Äù As Prince of Wales, King Charles has visited the Republic of Ireland a number of times on behalf of the British Government. On one such occasion, he told Deputy Flanagan he hoped to travel to all 32 counties on the island. Could his next visit include a stop in Drum? David Stewart and his father, William, chuckled at the suggestion. ‚ÄúWell, we wouldn‚Äôt kick him out,‚Äù William laughed. ‚ÄúBut I can‚Äôt see that happening.‚Äù Main image: David and William Stewart with a plate with King George on it. April 2024. Image: Newstalk

title: Microsoft admits new bugs in Windows 11 Version 24H2 Update
text:
Users have reported issues such as the address bar overlapping with content in full-screen mode, blocking access to Home and Gallery icons, and the "See more" or "More options" menus appearing at the top of the screen instead of below the cursor.
Some menu options are becoming inaccessible when File Explorer is in full-screen mode.
Additionally, the mouse cursor disappears when interacting with text input, File Explorer's top bar is slow to load, typing a path in the address bar is reportedly not always working properly, and things crash when creating new folders in certain locations.
Microsoft has confirmed that fixes for these issues are being developed. Some patches have already been included in the Beta Channel build for Windows 11 23H2 and are expected to roll out to 24H2 users in upcoming updates.
For now, users are advised to use File Explorer in windowed mode instead of full-screen, resize the File Explorer window to access menu options, and try to use keyboard shortcuts. The first security update of 2025 for Windows 11 is scheduled for Jan. 14, which may include some of these fixes.
We have not been able to test any of this because our main computer will not install the upgrade, it just downloads it and has a snooze. We did a check and there are a few people on the worldwide wibble who have a similar problem.
